caseTitle: NANA KWEKU BOFA, V NANA KOFI KUM
summary: This 1940 decision of the West Africa Court of Appeal dismissed an appeal for lack of jurisdiction. The appellant, Nana Kofi Kum, Ohene of Korase, sought to appeal a decision from the Chief Commissioner of Ashanti's Court but could not point to any statutory provision granting the Court of Appeal jurisdiction. Relying on section 8 of the West African Court of Appeal Ordinance (Cap. 5), which allows the court to entertain appeals 'on any terms which it thinks just,' the court held that this provision does not confer general appellate jurisdiction but is limited to cases where an appeal already lies under other statutory provisions. The court affirmed the preliminary objection, citing the unreported 1932 decision in Dovlo Kudiabor v. Hutohoke Kudanu, and dismissed the appeal with costs of Â£28 11s. 6d.
legalKeywords: West African Court of Appeal Ordinance
verdict: Appeal dismissed for lack of jurisdiction.
citations: Dovlo Kudiabor v. Hutohoke Kudanu (unreported, 14th November 1932)
West African Court of Appeal Ordinance (Cap. 5), s 8
rationaleHighlights: Section 8 of the West African Court of Appeal Ordinance does not confer general appellate jurisdiction
Jurisdiction under s 8 is limited to appeals authorized by other statutory provisions
No express enactment granting jurisdiction to hear the appeal
Preliminary objection upheld for lack of jurisdiction
confidenceNotes: The case is clearly reported with judicial reasoning and citation to prior unreported authority; factual accuracy is high based on the official court format and structured judgment.
